text:
I am looking for *experienced Technical writers or Product content writers* who can join our team full time!!

Responsibilities include technical writing for our platform and release notes. Writing new help content and optimizing existing content in our Help Center.

Requirements for this role:
• 3+ years of proven technical or content writing experience – *preferably in SaaS companies*
• *Digital marketing experience is a plus*, especially in the field of Facebook, Instagram, and Google advertising
• Ability to create high-quality, long-form user assistance content for *software products*
You can visit more details about our job opening here: <https://madgicx.com/career/product-content-writer>

Join us in creating Madgicx!

attachments.text: As a Product Content Writer, you will also be responsible for technical writing for our platform and release notes. Every week, our Product teams release new tools and updates to our software, and you will be in charge of keeping our users in the loop and our platform’s UX impeccable.

text:
Hey all.
I’m looking for some freelance writers to help with some thought leadership content <https://www.outloudgroup.com/post/influencer-brief|like this> for our influencer marketing agency. The writers wouldn’t need to come up with the thought leadership but would be adapting it either from other formats (youtube videos/presentations) or from a detailed outline. *Really, I just need someone who can turn ugly writing into pretty writing.* If that sounds like you or someone you know, can you DM me some work samples and your estimated rate for 1000-1500 words?

text:
Question about pricing for freelance copywriting:

I'm drafting a proposal for a mid-sized established Ed-tech software company.

They want me to rewrite the copy for their entire website, which includes the home page, about us, 5 product pages, and tertiary pages beneath that. 

They already have the design mocked up (not ideal, i know). I explained that I need to research competition to inform positioning and overall messaging. But overall they just want me to refresh the copy. 

How much would you charge? Instead of charging per page, I'm thinking a bundled package price (+ rush fee). 

Thanks for your help and insight :pray:

How much would you charge? Instead of charging per page, I'm thinking a bundled package price (+ rush fee).
Thanks for your help and insight

text:
from <@U03CNSHCX9C>: As someone who worked in edtech for 6.5 years I’m suuuuuuper curious to know who, lol. :eyes:

Edtech is booming right now … I’d probably put together a pretty strong number. Folks who have recently done contracted work probably have better/more specific advice for you on the exact amount, but I’m pretty well-versed in the space if you want more context into how strong their budget might be right now.

text: I run an edtech startup and a copywriting agency so this is right up my alley. I'd say $16k-ish would be reasonable!

text:
Hey James! Not sure if this is helpful advice or not, but my pricing process would be to roughly estimate how many hours it’s going to take me for the whole project, add a little padding for communication and uncertainty (something will take longer than you expect), and then just multiply it by an hourly rate you’re comfortable with and present it as one price (without the hours breakdown).

I don’t know this industry specifically, but you can probably charge anything from $75-150+/hr (assuming you’re doing quality writing of course!). I’m sure there are people who charge way more than that, but it’s all about your comfort level, how much value you feel you’re adding, and what’s fair to you.

If you’re super uncertain about how long it will take you and you’re worried about taking on too much personal risk, you could propose an hourly rate with a maximum budget. i.e. “I’ll do this for $100/hr, up to 100 hours. If it’s going to exceed that, I’ll get budget approval before doing more work.” I’ve done that with a client before on a really weird project, but it’s normally better to avoid talk of hourly :stuck_out_tongue:

text:
Gotta love those "can you just refresh our copy" requests. I find that often means that budget/timeline aren't really aligned with what it takes to write good copy. It's always tricky, but you'll likely have to sell the value of what you can do as a copywriter, beyond making things sound nice. A lot of people don't realize how much goes into creating effective copy, so I'd start with educating them on your process and how research will lead to increased conversions.

I would also take into account your level of experience. If you haven't done web copy projects like this in the past, you'll probably want to charge a bit less than someone who has a lot of experience. There is a pricing calculator on Copyhackers that might be helpful for a ballpark: <https://copyhackers.com/freelance-copywriter-quote-calculator/>

Feel free to dm me if you want to chat more about how to approach. Happy to help however I can.

attachments.fallback: Copywriting for startups and marketers: What should you charge? Use this calculator.
attachments.text: Freelance copywriters use this calculator to figure out what to charge clients.
attachments.title: What should you charge? Use this calculator.

text:
<@UUH2ESL66> <@U03C0JYM4LV> <@U02RGBRUUE8> thank you for your replies! 

The total number of pages would be 40, but there's a lot of overlap between many of the pages (slightly different audiences for the same product - so slightly different value props).

I have about 4 years of content and email marketing experience, but this would be the second time I'm doing a full website (the other project was also in ed-tech).

16k seems scary to ask for, but more than reasonable at $400 per page (even with overlapping messaging between many pages).

text:
<@U035WGHQG3B> $16k for 40 pages is an absolute steal. If you haven’t seen the copy they need ‘refreshed’ just yet, I’d definitely take a look to make sure it’s salvageable!

Depending on how established this company is, I would absolutely go higher. For reference, I typically charge $5k for homepages, sales pages etc, and $1200 each for internal pages without a ton of content on them. And then throw in any transactional pages like 404s, contact etc for free.

text:
<@U02RGBRUUE8> that's encouraging to know! They are tying to make it sound like it's not THAT much work, because many of the pages have overlapping information. The company has been around since the year 2,000 and has 100-200 employees, but I don't know how much of profit/finding/budget they have.

Curious if you have any tips for justifying the price. I know value based pricing is the way to go if possible, but I'm not sure what their traffic and conversion rate is now and how much it would improve with my copy. (I can use a tool like Ahrefs to estimate traffic potential)

text:
If they have 100-200 employees, they can easily afford upwards of $16k!

So it’s tricky to say without knowing more about the client, but typically ask some variation of: “Why this problem? And why now?” on discovery calls and that gives me a good sense of what they’re looking to accomplish and what KPIs they’re using to measure the success of the project. I’ll then see how I can use that to position the pricing.

More often than that though, I use case studies, testimonials and spell out my process and really position myself as the expert. Most organizations understand that copy is just one piece of the puzzle and it can’t fix things like a crap product or a broken funnel. They just want to know that you know what you’re doing.

text: It depends on your niche expertise, client budget and a bunch of other factors. Range can be from $100 to $2500. But yeah, I wouldn't go below $100.
